title: Wildfire danger in Eagle County is pretty low , thanks to a cool , moist spring
message:
Mitigation efforts over the past several years have helped reduce the risk of wildfire, but nothing helps keep fire danger at bay like a lot of snow and a cool, moist spring.
Birch Barron, the county’s emergency management director, on Tuesday updated the Eagle County Board of Commissioners on current wildfire conditions in the area.
But, he noted, no part of Eagle County was in any form of drought at the end of April, adding that the county was bordering on “abnormally dry” at the end of April in 2023.
That snow is coming off fairly slowly, again thanks to a reasonably cool spring so far.
The good news from the cooler spring conditions applies to spring runoff.

title: Why is Texas prone to flooding in the spring ? Here how to find out if your home is in danger
message:
Texas is frequently battered by storm after storm in the spring, leaving a soggy landscape with nowhere to let all the rain out.
Texas’ version of the water cycle frequently causes flooding because of the state’s diverse terrain and location along the Gulf of Mexico.
A Blue Ribbon Study found that Texas had 4,722 flash floods during the 14-year period from 1986 to 2000.
Types of flooding most common in TexasGiven that Texas is located in “flash flood alley,” it is not shocking that more than 500 flash floods have been reported in the previous ten years.
The most vulnerable time of year for flooding in Texas depends on the type of flood.

title: Texas and Louisiana flooding : Rare high risk of extreme rainfall to trigger  life - threatening  flooding
message:
CNN —A dangerous, life-threatening flash flooding event is unfolding Thursday as torrential storms pound the already-soaked South.
A rare Level 4 of 4 high risk of excessive rainfall was issued for parts of eastern Texas and western Louisiana by the Weather Prediction Center Thursday.
Texas and Louisiana have been in the bull’s-eye of seemingly unrelenting rounds of torrential, flooding downpours since the start of April.
Rainfall rates up to 3 inches per hour are possible in the heaviest storms, which could lead to life-threatening flash flooding, according to the WPC.
Serious flash flooding is likely in any areas caught under multiple storms unloading 2 to 3 inches of rain per hour.

message:

Those under the tornado watch need to be prepared to seek shelter immediately if a tornado warning is issued for your location.
If you do not have a basement or storm shelter, seek shelter in an interior closet in the lowest level of your home.

title: Oregon officials say 2024 fire season threat slightly less than 2023
message:
PORTLAND Ore. (KPTV) - The threat of wildfires in Oregon for summer 2024 should be less than last year, at least for the early summer months, state forestry experts said on Wednesday.
That’s according to experts with the state’s forestry department - who provided a look at what we can expect as wildfire season approaches.
Oregon saw a considerable amount of rain and snow throughout the winter months, building a strong snowpack.
Tina Kotek, said this could mean more complex and challenging wildfire conditions in the later summer months.
The Department of Forestry said it’s preparing for the season by making sure resources are in place to fight fires when they do start, including new modernized equipment.

message:

Oregon wildfire officials said they are increasing the scale of prescribed burns across the state to prevent severe wildfires.

title: Looming fires force thousands of Canadians to evacuate . Some may not return home until next week
message:
CNN —Colossal wildfires burning across Canada over the last week have driven thousands of people to evacuate with their kids, pets and precious belongings in tow – many uncertain when they may be able to return home.
More than 6,000 people have evacuated from Fort McMurray in Alberta since Tuesday as a 51,000 acre fire burns less than 5 miles from the city’s edge.
Flames and smoke fill the air as wildfires burn nearby in Fort McMurray, Alberta, Canada on May 2016.

title: Army Corps prepares Lake Okeechobee ahead of  extremely active  hurricane season
message:
In February, the Corps implemented releases to the Caloosahatchee and St. Lucie Estuary to bring lake levels down ahead of the 2024 hurricane season, which is already forecasted to be “extremely active.”The plan worked.
As of Wednesday, May 15, 2024, Lake Okeechobee stands at 13.73 feet.
The 143-mile earthen dam system encircles Lake Okeechobee and is routinely inspected.
It reduces impacts from flooding as a result of high lake levels for a large area of south Florida.
On the cusp of this hurricane season, the Corps is prepared for it.

title: Canadian wildfires haze U . S . skies , trigger air quality warnings in multiple states
message:
Wildfire smoke has lowered air quality and made for some hazy skies in areas like Minneapolis and Kansas City this week.
The upper-level winds have shifted, which resulted in the smoke from these fires filtering into the United States.
On Tuesday, Code Orange (3 of 6) air quality was reported in cities like Topeka, Kansas.
The 2023 Canadian wildfire season was record-breaking with about 45 million acres burned, which is nearly two and a half times the previous record of 17.5 million acres burned in 1995.
While it is expected to be another busy wildfire season this year, it is also not expected to be anywhere near the activity and widespread as last year.

title: Fort Nelson , B . C ., wildfire expands to 127 sq km but cooler temps expected
message:
See more sharing optionsSend this page to someone via emailShare this item on TwitterShare this item via WhatsAppShare this item on FacebookBritish Columbia’s wildfire service says the blaze threatening the northern community of Fort Nelson now spans nearly 130 square kilometres, but it had spread away from the town along its southern flank.
The service says the Parker Lake fire has been mapped at 127 square kilometres in size, up from 84 square kilometres earlier this week.
It says cooler temperatures and higher relative humidity were expected to make for more favourable conditions over the next couple of days fighting the fire that was only two kilometres southwest of the town earlier this week.
Story continues below advertisementThere may be some light rain, but the BC Wildfire Service says it won’t be enough to “offset the prolonged drought and cause the fires to self-extinguish.”The email you need for the day's top news stories from Canada and around the world.
Rob Fraser, the mayor of the Northern Rockies Regional Municipality, which includes Fort Nelson, told a community meeting that he now feels confident they will get word eventually that the fire is not threatening the community.

title: Looming fires are forcing thousands of Canadians to evacuate . Some may not return home until next week
message:
Colossal wildfires burning across Canada over the last week have driven thousands of people to evacuate with their kids, pets and precious belongings in tow – many uncertain when they may be able to return home.
More than 6,000 people have evacuated from Fort McMurray in Alberta since Tuesday as a 51,000 acre fire burns less than 5 miles from the city’s edge.
But that is far from the amount of precipitation needed to offset drought conditions and extinguish the fires, the British Columbia Wildfire Service said.
Smoke rises as fire singes Fort Nelson on May 14.
“This region has experienced multiple years of drought, with a below normal snowpack this past winter,” said Ben Boghean, fire behavior specialist for the BC Wildfire Service.

title: Maritime weather : Wildfire , spring precipitation update
message:
Spring 2024 has so far been characterized by near normal precipitation totals for the Maritimes.
The season has been front loaded with the bulk of the total precipitation falling in the month of March.

title: Local officials keeping eye on busy hurricane season forecast
message:
Predictions are calling for a busier than usual Atlantic storm season, and Liberty County officials have begun getting organized for a potentially active summer and fall.
Hurricane season begins June 1 and ends November 30.
Forecasters at Colorado State University are predicting an unusually active Atlantic hurricane season, with 23 named storms, 11 hurricanes and five major hurricanes.
Water temperatures in the eastern and central Atlantic are at record warm levels and are expected to remain well above average for the upcoming hurricane season.
CSU’s forecast team anticipates a well above-average probability for major hurricanes making landfall along the U.S. coast for the 2024 hurricane season.

title: Prepare for the Coming Storm Season at Port St . Lucie 2024 Hurricane Expo

Port St. Lucie - Thursday May 16, 2024: Hurricane season is right around the corner, which makes now the perfect time to start preparing.
The 18th annual Hurricane Preparedness Expo will take place Saturday, June 1 from 10 a.m. to 2 p.m. at MIDFLORIDA Event Center, located at 9221 SE Event Center Place in Port St. Lucie.
This free, family-friendly event connects residents with businesses and emergency providers who can help them prepare for extreme weather situations.
This year’s Expo will feature informative presentations from meteorologists, emergency managers, City of Port St. Lucie staff and community organizations that can assist with hurricane preparations.

title: Cities look for new ways to keep people safe and alive as extreme summer heat looms
message:
“We prepare for heat year-round in Phoenix,” Mayor Kate Gallego said.
The 2023 heat waves revealed how challenging it can be to cope with extreme temperatures for weeks on end, even in places where residents are accustomed to warm weather.
That has prompted cities across the South and the Southwest to re-evaluate how best to keep people safe — and alive — this summer.
Gallego said Phoenix has been creating “cool corridors” by planting trees and resurfacing the pavement with more reflective coatings to reduce urban heat.
A primary focus right now is mitigating high overnight temperatures, which plagued the city last summer.

title: Firefighters Gain Control of One Blaze Threatening Oil Sands in Alberta
message:
(Bloomberg) -- Firefighters gained control of one wildfire near the main oil-sands region of Alberta on Wednesday, but continued to battle a much larger blaze to the south that’s threatening the area’s biggest city.
Workers based in Fort McMurray help staff the surrounding oil-sands operations that produce the bulk of Canada’s 4.9 million barrels of daily crude output.
“More than 2.1 million barrels per day of marketable oil sands output could be at risk should conditions materially worsen.”So far, no oil-sands producer has reported operational disruptions.
A devastating fire eight years ago leveled parts of Fort McMurray and forced the entire population to evacuate.
That blaze shut more than 1 million barrels of daily oil output for weeks and caused about C$3.7 billion ($2.7 billion) in insured losses, making it Canada’s costliest natural disaster.

Francis Asenso-Boakye, the roads minister, toured the area to assess the situation and later assured the press that the government would construct storm drains to help address the issue.

The new blaze near Fort McMurray, Alberta, is about 3 hectares (7 acres) in size, and is about 10 kilometers (6 miles) away from Suncor Energy Inc.’s Millennium and Steepbank mine sites, provincial data show.
Already, more than 6,000 people have been evacuated from Fort McMurray communities, and long-term prospects of rain extinguishing the blazes are low.
Winds were expected to weaken and push the fire away from Fort McMurray, helping firefighting efforts.

title: Buckle Up For More Dust Storms Thanks To Land Degradation , Climate Change
message:
In India dust storm and thunderstorm activity usually peak in the pre-monsoon period, between March and May.
The worst sand and dust storms India experienced was on May 2, 2018 when severe dust storms, thunderstorms and lightning hit several parts of India, resulting in the deaths of at least 124 people and injuries to 300 others.
Climate change — which is bringing droughts and more extreme temperatures — is amplifying these factors.
In some areas, desert dust has doubled in the 20th century, increasing the chance of sand and dust storms.
Combating sand and dust storms requires accelerated action and relevant capacity in multiple- hazard risk reduction for both adaptation and mitigation.

title: New Mexico getting $28 million for wildfire defense
message:
NEW MEXICO (KRQE) – Around New Mexico, 11 communities are getting a share of $28 million to boost wildfire defenses.
Otero County received $243,100 to develop a community wildfire protection plan for Otero County.
Valencia County received $159,600 to update and expand community wildfire protection plans throughout the county of Valencia, NM.
San Miguel County received $88,000 to update the San Miguel County community wildfire protection plan following the Hermits Peak/Calf Canyon Fire.
Mora County received $88,000 to update the Mora County community wildfire protection plan following the Hermits Peak/Calf Canyon Fire.

title: DeSantis signs bill deleting climate change mentions from Florida state law
message:
CNN —As Florida copes with rising seas and record temperatures, lawmakers are going to exceptional lengths to delete many mentions of climate change from state laws in a new bill that Republican Gov.
The wide-ranging law makes several changes to the state’s energy policy – in some cases deleting entire sections of state law that talk about the importance of cutting planet-warming pollution.
“It goes further than any other state has gone in repealing its existing climate laws,” Michael Gerrard, founder of the Sabin Center for Climate Change Law at Columbia University, told CNN.
DeSantis vetoed over $29 million dollars in federal energy rebates and energy efficiency grants from the Inflation Reduction Act and Bipartisan Infrastructure Law.
Hammond called focusing on adapting to climate change and hardening infrastructure without attribute it to a warming planet “consistent to the conservative approach.”“They don’t want to acknowledge that climate change is happening; they acknowledge they have flooding,” Gerrard said.

title: Tyson Foods CEO Unsure When Nation Collapsing Beef Herd Will Reverse
message:
Tyson Foods CEO Donnie King spoke at the BMO Global Farm to Market Conference in Toronto on Wednesday, expressing much uncertainty about when US ranchers will rebuild tight cattle herds meaningfully.
He stated ranchers had been pressured in recent years to offload cattle due to high grain costs and drought, which, in return, sent the nation's beef cattle herd plunging to the lowest in more than half a century.
All in all, King's comments did not provide confidence that the nation's beef cattle herd would reverse from seven-decade lows as ranches continue offloading cows to slaughterhouses.
The latest figures from the US Department of Agriculture show that the nation's cattle herd is 87.2 million head (as of Jan. 1), the lowest level since 1951.
This perfect storm has sent beef prices at the supermarket to record highs.

title: Sewage scandal water group to pay shareholders £320million
message:

That is 9.4% higher than last year and represents a £320million payday for its shareholders.
Lake Windermere, a Unesco world heritage site, had millions of litres of raw sewage pumped into itTrendingEarlier this week, United was engulfed in a storm after it emerged that it had pumped sewage into the iconic lake in February.
It blamed a telecoms fault which caused its main pumps to stop and for emergency pumps discharging untreated sewage into Windermere, a Unesco World Heritage site, for 10 hours.

title: Wildfire updates today : Fort McMurray , Fort Nelson
message:
At present, 76 of those fires are listed as under control, meaning further spread is prevented, with another 14 controlled enough to hold within predetermined boundaries and 30 spreading out of firefighter control.
A further nine active fires are under the jurisdiction of Parks Canada.
Seven large wildfires ranging from 3,300 to more than 80,000 hectares are now burning out of control near the community.
Meanwhile in Alberta, a nearly 20,000-hectare fire near Fort McMurrayshrunk slightly on Thursday and is about six kilometres from city limits.
Further information about local fires may be found through their respective provincial wildfire services.

title: Oregon prepares for above - average wildfire season amid firefighter staffing challenges
message:
Officials from the Oregon Department of Forestry and Oregon State Fire Marshal said Wednesday they expect an above-average wildfire season for July and August in eastern parts of the state.
"Just as we saw last weekend, temperatures are increasing in our state,” said Doug Grafe, wildfire adviser for Gov.
The Oregon Department of Forestry relies on more than 700 firefighters.
State Fire Marshal Mariana Ruiz-Temple said further complicating Oregon’s fire season is a dwindling pool of firefighters.
“On average, this investment brings about 1,600 firefighters, supports 1,600 firefighters during key fire season,” she said.

title: Hurricane Katrina victim identified nearly 2 decades after storm pounded Gulf Coast
message:
CBS News' Tracy Smith was in New Orleans after Hurricane Katrina hit, covering the crisis that followed the stormCBS News' Tracy Smith was in New Orleans after Hurricane Katrina hit, covering the crisis that followed the stormAlmost two decades after a woman's death during Hurricane Katrina, modern forensic tests finally allowed authorities to identify her remains.
Tonette Waltman Jackson's remains were identified in May 2024 — almost two decades after her death during Hurricane Katrina.
He added: "In 2005, when Jane Love or Tonette's remains were found, forensic genetic genealogy was not a tool that was available."
Earlier this month, testing on a DNA sample submitted by one of Jackson's close family members confirmed her identity.
Hardy Jackson gave an on-camera interview to CBS affiliate WKRG in the immediate aftermath of Hurricane Katrina and shared his wife's story.

title: Texas Will Feel The Wrath of La Niña , Starting This Summer
message:
The eastward winds of El Niño are fading, but a terrible little girl we know as La Niña is brewing on the horizon.
With El Niño, the temperatures in the eastern Pacific Ocean drop by half a degree Celsius; with El Niña, the inverse holds true.
The key difference between El Niño and La Niña in how it impacts Texas is that the former brings about a wet winter, the latter brings warmer, drier weather.
There may be a period of neutral weather, but we can expect a rapid cycle over to La Niña by June or August at the latest.
All aboard the Somewhat Small Texas Panhandle Towns tour!

title: Fort St . John eatery out of burgers as B . C . widlfire evacuees swell town
message:
Things looking up in Fort Nelson as blaze spreads away from town and conditions improveThe Denny’s restaurant in Fort St. John, B.C., ran out of burgers on Tuesday, a waiter said.
Fort St. John businesses have been doing their best to welcome the influx, offering free movie nights — popcorn included — and discount burritos.
The service says the Parker Lake fire has been mapped at 127 square kilometres in size, up from 84 square kilometres earlier this week.
For Fort St. John businesses, the impact of the influx of evacuees was almost immediate.
The BC Wildfire Service said the blaze about two kilometres west of the town now spans 127 square kilometres, up from 84 square kilometres earlier this week, but it has spread away from the town along its southern flank.

title: Severe storm threat increases across San Antonio . What can you expect ?
message:
SEVERE THREATSWhat’s new for San Antonio is the upgraded severe threat from the Storm Prediction Center.
San Antonio has been upgraded to a level 2 of 5 severe threat for the afternoon and evening.
National Weather ServiceAccording to the National Weather Service, once the capping inversion erodes around lunchtime, we will see isolated to widely scattered thunderstorms develop and quickly intensify.
FLOODING IS POSSIBLEIn addition to the severe thunderstorms, heavy rain is likely, especially east and north of San Antonio.
Heavy downpours are likely with any strong storms but the heaviest rain will happen north and east of San Antonio.

title: Flagstaff scientists to use satellites to spot new wildfires
message:
PHOENIX (AZFamily) — The fight to prevent destructive wildfires is a global issue, and scientists right here in Arizona are at the forefront.
Alexander Shenkin, an assistant research professor at Northern Arizona University, said all the fires are costing money, homes and forests.
That’s led NAU scientists, Flagstaff engineers, and fire leaders with the same passion for preventing wildfires to come together.
“This thing I’m holding is a 3D print one-to-one scale model of the camera that we’re going to put on our satellites,” Trilling said.

title: Rains Helping To Ease Iowa Drought | AM 600 WMT
message:
(Undated) -- This week's U.S. Drought Monitor shows continued improvement in Iowa.
Recent heavy rains have helped to lift more areas out of drought and to ease the severity of drought in other locations.
The driest conditions continue to be in northeast Iowa, where a large part of that region remains in severe drought.
The National Weather Service is predicting warm and dry weather for the next few days.
Forecasters are predicting active weather next week with more chances for storms.

title: Nebraska Drought Improves Slightly | NewsRadio 1110 KFAB
message:
(Lincoln, NE) -- Drought conditions in Nebraska improved slightly in the past week.
The U.S. Drought Monitor shows around 30-percent of the state as either abnormally dry or in moderate drought.
Iowa's drought picture has improved as well.
Most of Pottawattamie County, Iowa is in moderate drought.
The National Weather Service in Valley, NE predicts warm temperatures this weekend with a good chance at widespread showers and thunderstorms returning on Sunday.

title: Is the death rate of Tahoe trees getting better or worse ?
message:
– California red fir mortality increased to approximately 1.6 million dead trees across 63,000 acres in 2023 from ~1.3 million dead trees across 54,000 acres in 2022.
– In 2023, white fir mortality decreased to 6 dead trees from an estimated 14,000 dead trees across 1,500 acres in 2022.
18- Tahoe National Forest– Mortality increased to an estimated 6.5 million dead trees across 330,000 acres in 2023 from ~5 million dead trees across 260,000 acres in 2022.
– California red fir mortality increased to approximately 6 million dead trees across 290,000 acres in 2023 from ~3.8 million dead trees across 170,000 acres in 2022.
– White fir mortality decreased to approximately 160,000 dead trees across 22,000 acres in 2023 from ~890,000 dead trees across 74,000 acres in 2022.

title: Less than a third of Iowa has drought
message:
(Courtesy of National Drought Mitigation Center)The state’s dryness has subsided to a level comparable with about a year ago, and less than a third of Iowa now has drought, according to the U.S. Drought Monitor.
A Thursday report — which is a snapshot of the conditions two days before — said about 27% of the state has some measure of drought.
Almost all of the remaining drought resides in the northeast quadrant of the state, and most of that drought is classified as “severe.”About 92% of the topsoil in farm fields has adequate or surplus moisture for growing crops, the USDA reported Monday.
Those totals might exceed two inches in parts of northern and eastern Iowa.

title: ESA - Canada wildfire season begins
message:
Applications Canada’s wildfire season begins 16/05/2024 171 views 3 likesWildfire season has arrived in full force in Canada, prompting evacuation orders and alerts in several towns in British Columbia and Alberta due to the danger of uncontrolled blazes.
The 2023 wildfire season in Canada was one of the worst on record.
With the 2024 wildfire season already in full swing, Canadian authorities are bracing for a challenging summer.
Wildfire season in Canada typically runs from April until September or October when cooler temperatures dampen fire activity.
As the wildfire season progresses, ESA’s World Fire Atlas continues to be a valuable resource in tracking new fire outbreaks.

title: John Swinney confirms support Fife residents affected by Storm Gerrit
message:
John Swinney announced on Thursday that funds will be made available to Fife Council to support households and businesses in Cupar flooded as a result of Storm Gerrit, on the same basis as the support provided to those worst affected by Storm Babet.
Swinney said the Scottish Government takes the issue of flood resilience “very seriously”, adding that the grant will be made available for residents “as swiftly as possible”.
Dear WillieFlood support for Cupar residents and businessesThank you for raising the issue of support for Cupar residents and businesses impacted by flooding from Storm Gerrit.
We know that in the face of climate change improving flood resilience is one of the largest adaptation challenges we face.
Responsibility for flood resilience is primarily that of the occupier of a property, and then for a Local Authority to consider community level resilience.

title: Cities look for new ways to keep people safe and alive as extreme summer heat looms
message:
Ward and her colleagues specialize in “heat governance,” helping local and state governments prepare for extreme heat events.
The work includes finding ways to mitigate heat and develop emergency responses for major heat waves.
Ward said that it’s heartening to see cities take extreme heat seriously but emphasized that major challenges lie ahead.
For one, preparing early for extreme heat requires funding, which is a major challenge, especially for rural communities.
Even trickier will be addressing the underlying social issues that get magnified during heat waves, such as homelessness, rising energy costs and economic inequality.

title: Every united kingdom town at risk of flooding this weekend as Brits warned of travel chaos
message:
Currently, 30 flood alerts are in place across the south of England including Canterbury, Swindon and Cambridge, as well as Luton and Winchester.
Flooding is likely tonight as nearly one month's rainfall is expected to batter the UK in just a few hours, the Met Office said.
Loss of power is likely, homes and businesses could be damaged and hail and lightning will become hazardous for many.
"Local flooding is also possible but not expected more widely across England today (Thursday) and again on Friday and Saturday.
Flood alert area: Areas at risk from Groundwater flooding including Caterham Bourne, Coulsdon Bourne, Beddington, Carshalton, Coulsdon, Kenley, Purley, South Croydon, Whyteleafe, Bromley, Bexley, Greenwich and Lewisham."

title: The Joint Recovery Action Plan ( JRAP ) in Nepal receives £13 Million from FCDO to meet the critical needs of Western Nepal Earthquake - affected population - Nepal
message:
“The Joint Recovery Action Plan was developed to respond the needs of the disaster-affected communities and to build resilience," said Ms. Hanaa Singer Hamdy, the UN Resident and Humanitarian Coordinator in Nepal.
The funding will address the water sanitation and hygiene (WASH), nutrition, protection, shelter, and food security needs of approximately 50 thousand earthquake-affected people in western Nepal.
The Chief Executive of the NDRRMA Mr. Anil Pokhrel said, “FCDO has been consistently supporting the Government of Nepal’s Humanitarian Response including reconstruction and recovery.
Out of the total funding need, FCDO is providing GBP 13 million (equivalent to USD 16.2 million).

title: Centre must revise parameters for State to declare Idukki drought - hit , says Prasad
message:
Addressing the media after inspecting the affected areas, primarily comprising cardamom plantations, in Idukki on Thursday, Mr. Prasad reiterated the State government’s call to the Central authorities to revise the drought parameters.
‘Send special team’He said the State government would request the Centre to dispatch a special team to assess the drought situation in the State, particularly in Idukki.
“Only a visit by a special team can confirm the reality of the drought situation in the State.
Financial assistance from the Centre is crucial to mitigate this crisis,” Mr. Prasad said.
Accompanied by Water Resources Minister Roshy Augustine, Mr. Prasad led a team that toured the drought-affected cardamom-growing areas in Idukki.

title: Canadian oil sands city evacuated as wildfire draws near
message:
Resident Ashley Russell was packed and ready to leave on a moment’s notice, as the rest of the city was put on alert.
“We’re seeing extreme fire behaviour,” Alberta Wildfire spokeswoman Josee St-Onge told a news conference.
Fears of 2016 repeatIn 2016, the entire city with a population of more than 90,000 was evacuated while production of 1 million barrels of oil per day — almost one third of Canada’s total output at the time — stopped.
Thousands of residents never returned to the city.
Rob Fraser, the mayor of Fort Nelson told AFP: “It’s cool, it’s overcast and the wind is just very slight.

title: Congressional Delegation On $60M From Inflation Reduction Act To Strengthen Water Security In Rio Grande Basin
message:
Representatives Teresa Leger Fernández (D-N.M.), Melanie Stansbury (D-N.M.), and Gabe Vasquez (D-N.M.) are announcing $60 million from the Inflation Reduction Act to help Doña Ana and Sierra County residents and farmers with drought mitigation and climate adaptation efforts, which will strengthen water security in the Rio Grande Basin.
“New Mexicans are regularly seeing the effects of climate change and long-term aridification on the Rio Grande.
Shorter irrigation seasons and an increased reliance on groundwater pumping demonstrate the dramatic changes the Rio Grande has undergone as our water resources decline,” Heinrich said.
This funding from the Inflation Reduction Act means communities in New Mexico will now have more resources to protect the Rio Grande and the clean, essential water supply it brings to the state.
In 2022, Heinrich and Luján wrote to DOI Assistant Secretary Tanya Trujillo requesting that DOI allocate funds appropriated by the Inflation Reduction Act to support drought mitigation, resilience, and Tribal and Pueblo irrigation and water needs in the Rio Grande Basin.
